title: Behavior of a function defined as an integral

content.question:
Let g be the function given by <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>g</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mrow> <msubsup> <mo>∫</mo> <mn>1</mn> <mi>x</mi> </msubsup> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> </mstyle> <mn>00</mn> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <msup> <mi>t</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msup> <mo>−</mo> <mn>3</mn> <mi>t</mi> <mo>+</mo> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mtext> </mtext> <msup> <mi>e</mi> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <msup> <mi>t</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msup> </mrow> </msup> <mtext> </mtext> <mi>d</mi> <mi>t</mi> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5587@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. Which of the following statements about g must be true?

I. g is increasing on (1, 2).

II. g is increasing on (2, 3).

III. g(3) > 0

topic.text: 5.3: Determining Intervals on Which a Function Is Increasing or Decreasing

skill.text: Skill 3.D: Apply an appropriate mathematical definition, theorem, or test.
